title: Chapter 3: Network Operations - Comprehensive Quiz
description: Test your knowledge of network operations including documentation, monitoring, performance management, change management, backup/DR, high availability, diagramming, and automation.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of network documentation?
options: To provide accurate reference for troubleshooting, planning, and compliance
To keep network engineers busy during downtime
To impress auditors with detailed diagrams
questions.explanation: Network documentation serves multiple critical purposes: troubleshooting reference, capacity planning, change management, compliance, and knowledge transfer. It's essential for operational efficiency and risk management.

questions.question: Which SNMP version provides authentication and encryption for secure monitoring?
questions.explanation: SNMPv3 is the only version that provides authentication (using SHA or MD5) and encryption (using AES or DES). SNMPv1 and v2c use community strings sent in clear text, which is insecure.

questions.question: What protocol is commonly used to collect flow data from routers and switches for traffic analysis?
questions.explanation: NetFlow (developed by Cisco) collects IP traffic flow data including source/destination IPs, ports, protocols, and byte counts. It's essential for traffic analysis, capacity planning, and security monitoring.

questions.question: What syslog severity level indicates error conditions that should be investigated?
questions.explanation: Syslog Level 3 (Error) indicates error conditions that should be investigated. Level 0 is Emergency (system unusable), Level 6 is Informational (normal events), and Level 7 is Debug (detailed troubleshooting info).

questions.question: Your network baseline shows 95th percentile utilization at 85 Mbps on a 100 Mbps link. What should you do?
options: Plan for capacity upgrade, as utilization exceeds 70% threshold
Reduce traffic by blocking non-critical applications
questions.explanation: Industry best practice recommends planning capacity upgrades when sustained utilization exceeds 70% (some use 80%). At 85% utilization, the link is approaching saturation and will likely experience performance degradation during peak periods.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between traffic shaping and traffic policing?
options: Shaping buffers excess traffic; policing drops excess traffic
Shaping is for ingress only; policing is for egress only
Shaping uses queues; policing uses access lists
There is no difference, they are synonyms
questions.explanation: Traffic shaping buffers excess packets to smooth traffic to a specified rate, introducing latency. Traffic policing drops or marks excess packets immediately without buffering. Shaping is typically used on egress, policing on ingress.

questions.question: What does RPO (Recovery Point Objective) measure?
questions.explanation: RPO (Recovery Point Objective) is the maximum acceptable amount of data loss measured in time. For example, an RPO of 1 hour means you can tolerate losing up to 1 hour of data. RTO measures maximum acceptable downtime.

questions.question: What does RTO (Recovery Time Objective) measure?
options: Maximum acceptable downtime to restore service
questions.explanation: RTO (Recovery Time Objective) is the maximum acceptable time to restore service after a failure. For example, an RTO of 4 hours means service must be restored within 4 hours of an outage.

questions.question: What is the 3-2-1 backup rule?
options: 3 copies of data, 2 different media types, 1 off-site copy
questions.explanation: The 3-2-1 rule is a backup best practice: maintain 3 copies of data (production + 2 backups), on 2 different media types (e.g., disk and tape/cloud), with 1 copy stored off-site for disaster recovery.

questions.question: If you perform a full backup on Sunday and incremental backups Monday through Friday, what do you need to restore data from Thursday?
options: Sunday's full backup and Thursday's incremental
Sunday's full backup and all incremental backups Monday through Thursday
questions.explanation: Incremental backups only back up changes since the last backup (any type). To restore Thursday's data, you need: Sunday's full backup + Monday's incremental + Tuesday's incremental + Wednesday's incremental + Thursday's incremental.

questions.question: What type of DR site has equipment installed but not configured or running, requiring several hours to activate?
questions.explanation: A warm site has equipment installed (servers, network gear) but not fully configured or running. It can be activated in 2-8 hours. Cold sites are empty shells (days to activate), while hot sites are fully operational (minutes to activate).

questions.question: What ITIL framework is used to manage changes to IT infrastructure?
questions.explanation: Change Management is the ITIL process for controlling the lifecycle of all changes to IT infrastructure. It includes RFC (Request for Change), CAB approval, implementation planning, testing, and post-implementation review.

questions.question: What is a CAB in the context of change management?
questions.explanation: CAB (Change Advisory Board) is a group of stakeholders who review and approve changes. It typically includes representatives from IT, security, operations, and business units to assess change impact and risk.

questions.question: During a firmware upgrade, at which point should you make the GO/NO-GO decision?
options: After upgrading the secondary device and verifying operation
questions.explanation: Best practice: upgrade the secondary device first, verify full operation (GO/NO-GO decision point), then proceed to upgrade the primary. This prevents cascading failures if the firmware is problematic.

questions.question: What availability percentage corresponds to 'four nines' uptime?
questions.explanation: 99.99% availability is 'four nines', allowing approximately 52 minutes of downtime per year. 99.9% is 'three nines' (8.76 hours/year), 99.999% is 'five nines' (5.26 minutes/year).

questions.question: If two components with 99.9% availability are configured in parallel (redundant), what is the overall availability?
questions.explanation: Parallel availability: A = 1 - ((1-A1) × (1-A2)) = 1 - ((1-0.999) × (1-0.999)) = 1 - (0.001 × 0.001) = 1 - 0.000001 = 0.999999 = 99.9999% (six nines). Redundancy dramatically improves availability.

questions.question: What HSRP priority value should the primary router have if the default is 100?
questions.explanation: HSRP uses priority to determine the active router (higher value wins). Default is 100. Best practice is to set the primary to 110+ and secondary to 100 (default), providing a clear priority difference.

questions.question: What does HSRP 'preempt' do?
options: Allows lower priority router to become active
Allows higher priority router to reclaim active role when it comes back online
questions.explanation: HSRP preempt allows a router with higher priority to take over the active role when it comes online or recovers. Without preempt, the current active router remains active even if a higher priority router becomes available.

questions.question: What LACP mode should be configured on both sides of an EtherChannel for it to negotiate properly?
questions.explanation: LACP 'active' mode actively negotiates EtherChannel formation. Best practice is to configure both sides as 'active'. 'Active-passive' also works. 'On' mode forces EtherChannel without negotiation (no LACP). 'Desirable' is PAgP, not LACP.

questions.question: What IP addressing notation should be used in network diagrams according to industry standards?
questions.explanation: Industry best practice is to use CIDR notation (e.g., 10.0.0.0/24) in network diagrams. It's more concise, easier to read, and universally understood. Decimal notation (255.255.255.0) is verbose and deprecated in documentation.

questions.question: What color is typically used in network diagrams to represent security devices like firewalls?
questions.explanation: Red is the standard color for security devices (firewalls, IPS) in network diagrams. Blue typically represents network devices (switches, routers), green for servers, yellow for wireless, orange for WAN/Internet connections.

questions.question: What should every professional network diagram include?
options: Legend, title block with version/date, and IP addresses
questions.explanation: Professional network diagrams must include: legend (symbols/colors), title block (title, version, date, author, approver), IP addresses in CIDR notation, device names, and interface labels. Both physical and logical information may be included depending on diagram type.

questions.question: What Ansible connection type is used for network devices like Cisco switches?
questions.explanation: Ansible uses 'network_cli' connection type for network devices. This is specifically designed for devices with command-line interfaces like Cisco IOS, Arista EOS, Juniper Junos. It's not standard SSH or paramiko.

questions.question: What configuration management tool uses 'playbooks' written in YAML to automate network configurations?
questions.explanation: Ansible uses 'playbooks' written in YAML to define automation tasks. Puppet uses manifests, Chef uses recipes, and SaltStack uses states. Ansible is agentless and particularly popular for network automation.

questions.question: What Ansible module collection is used to configure Cisco IOS devices?
questions.explanation: The cisco.ios collection provides modules for Cisco IOS and IOS-XE devices (Catalyst switches, ISR routers). cisco.nxos is for Nexus switches, cisco.iosxr is for IOS-XR routers, cisco.asa is for ASA firewalls.

questions.question: What port security violation mode drops unauthorized packets but keeps the port operational?
questions.explanation: 'Restrict' mode drops packets from unauthorized MACs, logs violations, and increments a counter, but keeps the port up. 'Shutdown' disables the port (requires manual intervention). 'Protect' drops silently without logging.

questions.question: What does 'mac-address sticky' do in port security configuration?
options: Learns MAC addresses dynamically and saves them to running config
Forces manual entry of all MAC addresses
questions.explanation: 'Mac-address sticky' dynamically learns MAC addresses (like normal learning) but saves them to the running configuration. This persists the learned MACs across reboots without manual entry.

questions.question: What is the purpose of IPAM (IP Address Management) documentation?
options: To track only static IP assignments
To track all IP address assignments, DHCP scopes, and subnet allocations
questions.explanation: IPAM (IP Address Management) tracks all IP address assignments (static and dynamic), DHCP scopes, subnet allocations, DNS records, and VLAN assignments. It prevents IP conflicts and aids in capacity planning.

questions.question: What is GFS (Grandfather-Father-Son) in backup strategy?
options: A backup rotation scheme with daily, weekly, and monthly retention tiers
questions.explanation: GFS (Grandfather-Father-Son) is a backup rotation scheme: Son = daily backups (short retention), Father = weekly backups (medium retention), Grandfather = monthly/yearly backups (long retention). It balances storage costs with recovery needs.

questions.question: Your company requires 99.99% availability (52 minutes downtime/year). Which DR site type is MOST appropriate?
questions.explanation: 99.99% availability allows only 52 minutes downtime annually. A hot site (RTO in minutes) is most appropriate. Warm sites (2-8 hours RTO) would exceed the annual budget. Cold sites (days) are completely inadequate.

questions.question: What is the primary advantage of using Oxidized or RANCID for network device backups?
options: They automate configuration backups and track changes with version control
questions.explanation: Oxidized and RANCID (Really Awesome New Cisco Config Differ) automatically connect to network devices, pull configurations, and store them with version control (Git). They track changes over time and alert on modifications.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a baseline in performance management?
options: To establish normal operating parameters for comparison and capacity planning
questions.explanation: A baseline documents normal network behavior (utilization, latency, errors) during typical operation. It's used to detect anomalies, plan capacity upgrades, and troubleshoot performance issues by comparing current metrics to baseline.

questions.question: What statistical measure is commonly used for capacity planning to ignore brief traffic spikes?
questions.explanation: The 95th percentile is industry standard for capacity planning. It ignores the top 5% of traffic spikes (brief anomalies) while capturing sustained high utilization. This provides a realistic picture of typical peak usage.

questions.question: You configure QoS with priority queue for VoIP at 2 Mbps on a 100 Mbps link. What percentage of bandwidth is reserved for VoIP?
questions.explanation: 2 Mbps / 100 Mbps = 0.02 = 2%. Priority queues should typically be limited to <33% of total bandwidth to prevent starving other traffic classes. VoIP uses relatively little bandwidth but requires priority treatment.

questions.question: What DSCP marking is typically used for VoIP traffic to ensure highest priority?
questions.explanation: DSCP EF (Expedited Forwarding, value 46) is used for highest priority traffic like VoIP. AF31 is for business-critical data, CS0 is default/best-effort, CS1 is scavenger/bulk traffic.

questions.question: What is a Single Point of Failure (SPOF)?
options: A device with high error rates
A component whose failure causes entire system failure
questions.explanation: A SPOF (Single Point of Failure) is any component whose failure would cause complete system or service failure. High availability designs aim to eliminate SPOFs through redundancy at all layers.

questions.question: What does MTBF (Mean Time Between Failures) measure?
options: Average time a component operates before failing
questions.explanation: MTBF (Mean Time Between Failures) is the average time a component operates before failing. Higher MTBF indicates more reliable equipment. MTTR (Mean Time To Repair) measures average repair time.

questions.question: If a full backup takes 6 hours and you have a 4-hour maintenance window, what backup strategy should you use?
questions.explanation: Full backup weekly (during longer weekend window) + incremental daily (fast, only changed files) fits within constraints. Incremental backups are quick (minutes), allowing daily execution within the 4-hour window.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between a physical and logical network diagram?
options: Physical shows cables and ports; logical shows IP addresses and VLANs
Physical shows servers; logical shows switches
Physical is for documentation; logical is for troubleshooting
questions.explanation: Physical diagrams show physical layout (rack locations, cable types, port numbers, patch panels). Logical diagrams show network architecture (IP addresses, VLANs, routing, subnets) independent of physical location.

questions.question: What is the primary benefit of network automation with tools like Ansible?
options: Eliminates the need for network engineers
Ensures consistent configurations and reduces human error
questions.explanation: Network automation's primary benefits are consistency (same configuration on all devices), reduced human error, faster deployment, and easier compliance. It complements (not replaces) skilled engineers and documentation.

questions.question: In Ansible, what keyword is used to iterate over a list of items?
questions.explanation: Ansible uses the 'loop' keyword to iterate over lists. Items are accessed with '{{ item }}'. Older versions used 'with_items', but 'loop' is the current standard.

questions.question: What is the correct order for upgrading redundant core switches to minimize risk?
options: Upgrade primary first, verify, then secondary
Upgrade secondary first, verify, then primary
questions.explanation: Always upgrade secondary (standby) first, verify full operation (GO/NO-GO decision), then upgrade primary. If secondary fails, you can rollback without impacting production (primary still active).

questions.question: What command in Ansible ensures configuration changes are saved to startup-config?
questions.explanation: The cisco.ios.ios_config module uses 'save_when: always' parameter to automatically save running-config to startup-config after changes. This ensures configurations persist across reboots.

questions.question: What security protocol should be disabled on access layer switch ports to prevent reconnaissance?
questions.explanation: CDP (Cisco Discovery Protocol) should be disabled on access ports (user-facing) because it reveals device information (model, IOS version, IP addresses) useful for attackers. Keep CDP enabled on trunk/uplink ports for management.

questions.question: What is the purpose of HSRP 'track' command?
options: To decrease priority if monitored interface/object fails
questions.explanation: HSRP 'track' monitors interface status or object state. If the tracked interface fails, priority is decremented (typically by 20), potentially causing failover to the standby router. This ensures the router with working uplinks is active.

questions.question: You have hourly incremental backups and weekly full backups. On Friday, the system fails. How many backups do you need to restore?
options: Sunday's full + Monday through Friday incrementals (6 backups total)
All backups from the past month
questions.explanation: With incremental backups, you need: last full backup (Sunday) + all incremental backups since then (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday) = 6 backups total. Incremental only backs up changes since last backup of any type.

questions.question: What is the recommended minimum baseline period for establishing network performance metrics?
questions.explanation: Industry best practice recommends 2-4 weeks minimum for baselines to capture weekly patterns and normal variations. Ideally, baseline for 30 days to include month-end processing patterns. 1 day or 1 week may not capture typical patterns.

questions.question: What diagram type shows rack locations, cable types, and physical port connections?
questions.explanation: Physical diagrams show the physical layout including rack locations, cable types (Cat6, fiber), port numbers, and physical connections. Wiring diagrams are more detailed (specific ports/panels), logical diagrams show IP/VLAN architecture.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a PIR (Post-Implementation Review) in change management?
options: To evaluate change success, identify issues, and document lessons learned
questions.explanation: PIR (Post-Implementation Review) evaluates change success against objectives, identifies issues encountered, documents lessons learned, and verifies the change met requirements. It's essential for continuous improvement of the change process.

questions.question: Your network has two components in series: Component A (99.9% availability) and Component B (99.5% availability). What is the overall system availability?
questions.explanation: Serial availability: A_total = A1 × A2 = 0.999 × 0.995 = 0.994005 ≈ 99.4%. Serial components multiply their availabilities, resulting in lower overall availability than any individual component. This demonstrates why redundancy is critical.
